BLUE.raw_line: I'm taking your train.Unlock your cab or. Doyle seems dazed, in a trance. Blue presses on the barrel of his gun, depressing Doyle's cheek.Pay attention to me. Open your cab door or I '.11 kill you.All right, Mr. Green?Then get it started. Green moves over to face the controls. He stares down at them for a moment, then reaches with his left hand to the controller, his right to the brake handle. Pressing down firmly on the controller, he nudges it to the left.Keep going --What happened?You said you could drive this thing.That's right, Mr. Green -- tell him all about yourself.You'll be hearing from Command Center in a minute )r two but you'll ignore the call -- you won't answer -- is that perfectly clear?Keep still!Any trouble, Mr.'Green?I unpacked your weapon. Get this thing moving -- we're run- ning almost two minutes behind. Picking up his submachine gun, and holding it vertically along his pants leg, Blue eases himself through the door and shuts it after him.And. you will remain silent! There will be no further warning -- any- one who moves or speaks without permission is going to be killed. There is immediate silence as he-looks around.This weapon fires 450 rounds of .45 calibre ammunition per minute. In other words, if all of you de- cided to rush me simultaneously, not a single one ,of you would get any closer than you are right now. Is that understood? This news is met in stony, awe-struck, terrified silence. Except for the Pimp who smiles, seemingly relaxed.Everybody in this half of the car -- that's from here on back -- move up front, please. Everybody. Right now -- upiGet going, Mr. Green. Green nods and goes to the front, uses a key to slide open the storm door, steps out and closes it again, then jumps down onto the tracks.Motorman -- come here.I want you to walk uptrack and collect all the passengers in the nine cars we out loose, and lead them back to the 28th St. Station -- is that clear?Just do as you're told: The Hooker raises her hand.No. No one else can leave.Nobody leaves!Yes. What's happening is that you're all being held by four dangerous men with machine guns.Please be quiet -- nothing's going to happen if you do as you're told. Get going, Motorman. As Doyle leaves at one end of the train, Green reappears at the other.All right, Mr. Green?I still see some tunnel lights.. Stay here -- and leave the cab door open so you can hear the radio. Blue returns to the center of the car but CAMERA stays on Green as he opens the cab door.What time've you got, Mr. Green?Correct. Time to start. Any- thing you want to say first?What do you want, Mr. Green?All right.Part of it.Recovering. They sounded a little upsat.Go back outside -- I don't want Mr. Brown and Mr. Grey left alone with the passengers any longer than we have to.I trust Mr. Brown -- Mr. Grey's another matter. He's a cocky little pain in the ass who could turn out to be real trouble if we don't watch him.He was recommended.Go on -- This is Pelham One Two Three, Trainmaster -- are you ready to take down the list of our demands?Do you have a pencil?To begin with it is important that you understand three things: One --Was he alone?Take over back there. I want Mr. Grey up closer to me so I dan keep an eye on him.Maybe it was necessary -- I didn't see it.What were you' calling about?It's 2:24, Lieutenant -- you still have 49 minutes.49 minutes.49 minutes.48 minutes.Everything quiet out here, Mr. Green?what do you mean?Which one?I'd better frisk him. Cover me. He walks slowly down the aisle and stops. in front of theOn your feet.You heard me -- stand up! Nervously, the man stands. Blue frisks him, quickly and expertly. When he fails to find a weapon, he takes the man's wallet.Okay -- you can sit down.School teacher.You ever been told you look like a policeman,?Listen to me, everybody. I'm sure you've' all figured out what' happening by now -- you're hostages.That means when we get what we,want you'll be released unharmed. Until then, you will continue doing precisely as you're told. _Don't worry -- they're going to pay. They have no choice.It wouldn't matter if all seventeen were dope pushers -- they have to pay, so relax.Then a lot of people are going to die.Either you live or you die.It depends. It's Y not better than trying to sell mutual funds, for example.I tried.I was. That's where I developed my expensive tastes.The Biafrans paid me twenty-five hundred for leading a battalion.The market dried up.What'd they nail you for?Beakies?You were innocent?Yes.I read you. Please take down the next set of instructions. As before, they're to be obeyed to the letter. First -- the money is to be paid in the following denominations: five hundred thousand dollars in fifties, five hundred thousand dollars in hundreds.Making a total of ten thousand fifty dollar bills and Alive thousand hundred dollar bills -- which will then be put up in stacks of two hundred bills each, bound with a thick rubber band lengthwise and another widthwise.Point two: all of the bills will be old bills, their serial numbers to erandom.That's all for now. When the delivery arrives we will contact you with further instructions.I'm signing off now.It's two-forty-seven, Prescott you have twenty-six minutes.Twenty-six minutes, Prescott.The city has agreed to pay for your release. No one quite knows how to greet this news -- except the Pimp who slowly, mockingly, claps his hands together.No -- but soon afterwards.What difference does it make?A million dollars.Altogether.Pull in your feet -- someone's liable to get hurt. The. Hippie looks up at him, smiles, and slides his feet back. Blue continues until he comes to Grey. He speaks quietly to him.Stop fooling around with that girl, Mr. Grey.I said leave her alone.Maybe we'll get a chance to work that out.They've requested more time.Ten minutes.I 'didn't -give it to them.Then we do what we said we'd do. There's no other way.An hour's plenty! You know how the system works -- you give them two hours and they take two -- three and they take three. An hour's plenty!I don't know. They're running pretty late.Mr. Green --Coming up on one minute.Mr. Brown.He won't mind.Mr.. Brown's better. With hint it's just a job -- not kicks. He looks at his watch as the.SUPERIMPOSED time continues to run: "3:12.07-08-09--toFifty seconds -- then we erase one.Return to your position, Mr. Grey.You heard me, Mr. Grey! I don't think there'll be any more.How does it feel?How many shots were there?We can't afford to. I'll go pick one cut.That's right, conductor. Would you come along with me, please?There's something you can help us with. Bud still hesitates.Don't worry, conductor -- comeAll you have to do is walk uptrack about a hundred feet and wait for the men delivering the money. They have reached the rear where Bud manages to avoid looking at Brown while Blue slides open the door.I'll help you down onto the track.One of my people was shot -- I warned you what the penalty would be.In the meantime, where's the money?Mr. Grey -- He gestures for Grey to join them which he does, his eyes on the money all the time.Get your things off -- both of you -- and start loading up. Blue watches while both Grey and :Brown remove their raincoats, jackets and finally their shirts. Brown has a blood-stained kerchief tied around his right upper arm. Both wear what can only be called money vests: canvas, sleeveless, fitting over the head like a Mae West, with ties on the sides, and containing pockets, 20 in all, front and back.Jr. Grey, you do Mr. Brown, then he'll do you -- nineteen packets each. Blue continues to observe for a mc-,ment as Grey starts inserting packets of pills, one to a pocket, into Brown's vest, as Brown stands stiffly, his hands at his sides. Then Blue walks to the front end of the car, joining Green.When they're finished it'll be your turn. Mr. Grey will load you up. But don't go down there until Nr. Brown has come here to take your place. I'll load up as soon as I talk-to Prescott.Pretty soon now. He goes into the motorman's cab and shuts the door.I'm going to give you five specific instructions. Each one i.s.to be followed precisely -- is that clear?One: at the end of this conversation you will restore power to the entire sector.Twos you will clear the local track all the way from 28th Street to South Ferry. By clear I mean switches properly set and all signals green. I emphasize green, Prescott -- if eve so much as see a red light, let alone get tripped by one, we will shoot a hostage.Three.: all southbound trains behind us, local and express, are to remain lying dead. Likewise all northbound between South Ferry and here.Four: you will con-",act me as soon as the track is clear and all signals are green.Five: you will remove all police personnel from the tunnel. If we see a single cop between here and South Ferry we will shoot a hostage. In fact, any deviation from these instructions and we will shoot a hostage.Your attention, please -- in a moment we're going to start moving again. You will all remain seated and quiet. We expect to release you unharmed in a short while, but until then you must continue doing exactly as you're told. Come along, Mr. Green. He heads for the motorman's cab, Green right behind him. The Pimp looks at Grey for a moment.Go ahead then.Go ahead, Mr. Green. Green edges the controller forward and the car responds.Keep it steady.No -- steady as she goes.Slight change of plan. We decided to put some distance between us and all those cops you had hidden in the tunnel back there.We'll be stopping soon. Just get back when you've cleared the rest of the track. Signing off. 'Perfectly natural under the circumstances. They're thinking just the way we want them to.Look sharp now -- it's comingDo you see it?All right -- this is close enough. Green starts to apply the brake.Ignore him -- he'll get tired and quit after a while. Let's get this stuff unpacked -- there isn't much time. They are unbuckling the straps and unfolding the canvas bag, then attacking the zipp`rs.Go ahead. Green attacks the windshield with tine stock of the gun, opening a great splintered hole.Get it all -- it's got to look right. Green uses the gun's barrel to scrape around the edges, clearing away the last traces of glass. Blue now hands Green another length of pipe -- this one about three feet long. Green fits one end over the protruding end of the attached short pipe -- not screwing it, merely fitting it. The other end extends straight out the glassless windshield.Try.it once -- make sure it comes away clean. Green yanks at the long pipe and it separates from the shorter one.Okay. Now j um_ down --- Ill hand the other oiece through. Green leaves the cab.Make sure its tight.Come on back in. Green returns to the storm door c There Brown extends his left hand and pulls Green back up into the car.Don't worry -- ten minutes from now we'll be free and clear.Thanks, Command Center. Give Prescott our regards.Over and out. He gives the mike a strong tug and-snaps the wire.I want this train moving in thirty seconds. Tell Mr. Brown and Mr. Grey they.rcan cut the emergency brake cords. Green leaves the cab. Blue examines the gimmick one last time, then follows Green out.You will remain in your seats. Don't try to get up.I mean remain seated. He has reached the rear, walking backwards, and now gropes behind him for the door handle.All right, Mr. Green -- Green, a hand on the protruding pipe connected to the controller handle inside the Motorman's cab, now grabs it with both hands and pushes inward, toward the train.Let's move along, gentlemen -- there's no time to waste. You all remember the drill. What's wrong, Mr. Brown?What did it look like?All right, we do it exactly as we did in the drill -- by the numbers.Shut up and do what you're told.Hats, glasses, wigs and mustaches -- They remove their disguises anal we see their faces for the first time.Remove gloves --Check handguns in coat pocket --Remove magazines from submachine guns. All of them pick up their submachine guns but only three remove the magazines and then place the guns back dcwn again. Grey merely watches the other three,. continuing to hold his gun under his arm, a slight smile on his face.Did you hear me, Mr. Grey? Disarm your gun and put it down so we can I get out of here.Put it down, Mr. Grey --Nothing's gone wrong. The plan depends on our walking away un- noticed. You can't do that carry- ing a submachine gun.You're leaving your gun here, Mr.Mr. Green will put it on over his own.You're the thinnest one -- it'll show less. Hurry up and undress. Mr. Brown -- help me with Mr. Grey. They start to work on the dead body as Green starts undressing.I'd never make it -- IQuiet! He listens again, then leaves his pillar, and hurries downtrack to the next where he again waits and listens,Mr. Green -- ! It's all right! Go on up -- I'll be right with you -- !You were on the train. Are you a cop? Almost imperceptibly, the Hippie nods -- just once.Then the Mayor will come to your funeral. X He lifts his gun to aim and fire and the Hippie manages to turn his head away. Then there's a shot -- and Blue crumples to the ground, dead.

GREEN.raw_line: Get rid of your seat. Doyle springs to his feet and swats up the folding seat with a clatter.Just take it easy. Now move over to the window -- and if you try to touch the mike pedal with your foot I'll shoot it off.A hundred percent.You say when, Mr. Blue.We're in no hurry.She must've bucked.It wasn't melWhat's your name, motorman?You ever been written up?What for?Twice. -- once on the Canarsie --Yeah -- I'm taking the brake handle and the reverse key, Denny -- and I want your cutting key, too. They're sure taking their time.The hostages. Yeah. At first I thought to myself, "Five of 'em are spades -- who's gonna pay anything for spades?" But they don't know who we've got, do they?I know they have to -- but what if they don't?Including us.Living's better.Did you do that?I thought you were in the army.In the army? Sure' -- on three-fifty a month.A month? Holy Christ l Why'd you ever get out of that?At least you weren't fired. But shit, I didn't mind -- who wants to drive a goddam subway train for the rest of.his life?Nothing! They framed me -- the goddam Beakies had to find a fall- guy and they --Transit inspectors -- undercover men. They got wind of a gang passing dope -- you know, transporting it from downtown to uptown, giving it to a motorman, and then someone picking it up in Harlem. The Beakies tried to pin it on me, but they never had any evidence..Hell yes, I was innocentl Do you think I'd do anything like that?I heard you on the radio -- anything wrong, Mr. Blue?How much more?I guess it won't hurt anything.Maybe an hour wasn't enough timeAnd what if it isn't?What?I guess not.Does he know?Neither would Mr. Grey.All that money -- I can't believeI just wish it was all over already.This is gonna hand 'em a jolt, you know -- moving before they expect it.We're coming in to 23rd Street.I'm still in switching -- can I push it up a notch?Do you think he's figured anything out? All those questions --It's that white light about a hundred feet ahead.Perfect fit. Blue now hands him a length of pipe, some six inches in length. Green takes it, fits one end into a socket on top of the gimmick, facing toward the windshield, and screws it in. Then Blue hands him his submachine gun. Green looks at him for reassurance.Perfect. He reattaches it.I did.It's all set to go. I only wish we were.That's not Prescott --This is crazy! Do what he says so we can get going!Oh my God -- Brown watches with a detachment bordering on disinterest.Me? Why me?Come on -- iI -- I'll wait for you -- 1 Blue looks at him fora moment, then checks his pistol and, slowly, steps out from behind the pillar. A shot rings out immediately and the ricochet off the pillar zings loudly. Blue calmly fires twice at the muzzle flash.Did you hit, him -- ?!
